channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russia Pounds Eastern Ukraine and Takes Dozens of Towns
item.description: After Russia scaled back its publicly stated ambitions in Ukraine, a senior Russian military commander said that Moscow wanted complete control of all eastern and southern Ukraine. It was unclear if his comments reflected an official shift in Kremlin policy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The Saltivka neighborhood of Kharkiv, Ukraine, was under continued attack Friday, as both shopping and residential areas were hit by bombs in the afternoon.

item.title: One Ukrainian War Casualty: The World’s Largest Airplane
item.description: Mriya, the world’s largest aircraft, was destroyed in a pivotal battle at the start of the war. It was a beloved symbol for all of Ukraine but perhaps no one misses it more than its first pilot.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Halunenko, the first pilot of Mriya, surveying damage to the world's largest cargo aircraft at the Antonov airfield in Hostomel, near Kyiv.

item.title: As Marine Le Pen Moves Closer to French Presidency, Putin Ties Persist
item.description: As elections approach Sunday, the far-right candidate is linked to the Russian president by a web of financial ties and a history of support that has hardly dimmed despite the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, left, the challenger for France’s presidency, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin in March 2017. She has supported his annexation of Crimea.

item.title: Aliou Cissé Has Senegal Ready to Shine in World Cup
item.description: Aliou Cissé, one of the best of a new generation of African coaches, has reinvented Senegal’s national team and given the country a new sense of patriotism. His next goal: the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Mady Camara
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senegal's national soccer team coach Aliou Cissé, 46, plays on a children's field in Diamiadio, Senegal on Thursday, March 31, 2022.

item.title: Who Will France’s Muslims Choose for President?
item.description: In Sunday’s decisive runoff election, they have a distasteful choice between Macron and Le Pen. They won’t necessarily back Macron.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Aida Alami
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Mosque of Bondy, in the Seine-Saint-Denis region outside of Paris, where Muslim anger toward President Emmanuel Macron and challenger Marine Le Pen runs strong.

item.title: Afghanistan Mosque Explosion Kills 33
item.description: The blast in Kunduz Province, in the north, was the latest in a series of attacks reminiscent of the past two decades of war.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:description: A child being treated for injuries at a hospital in Kunduz after a bomb blast earlier this week, on Thursday.

item.title: Brief Bouts of Unrest Erupt After Jerusalem Friday Prayers
item.description: The Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as Temple Mount, was once again the scene of clashes as tens of thousands of Muslims gathered to worship. But the violence ended quickly.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: President Moon Exchanges Farewell Letters With Kim Jong-un
item.description: President Moon Jae-in, who is barred from seeking re-election after his five-year term, and the North’s leader had warm parting words amid a diplomatic stalemate.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korea Summit Press Pool, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea holding hands at the border line between their two countries, in 2018.

item.title: E.U. Takes Aim at Social Media’s Harms With Landmark New Law
item.description: The Digital Services Act would force Meta, Google and others to combat misinformation and restrict certain online ads. How European officials will wield it remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Since Europe’s General Data Protection Regulation took effect in 2018, little action has been taken against the data-collection practices of large internet platforms.

item.title: New Zealand Deal May Put Japan Closer to Intelligence Alliance
item.description: The two countries announced a goal of “seamless” sharing of classified information as China moves to expand its influence in the Asia-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan and Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand in Tokyo on Thursday.

item.title: Mwai Kibaki, Former President of Kenya, Dies at 90
item.description: He came to power promising to root out corruption and improve government transparency. But his tenure was blighted by widespread graft and a violent upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: President Mwai Kibaki of Kenya in 2010 at the signing ceremony for Kenya's new Constitution, which promised greater freedoms and rights.

item.title: Explosion at Afghan Mosque Kills at Least 10
item.description: The blast in Mazar-i-Sharif, one of Afghanistan’s economic hubs, was the latest in a series of attacks on one of its religious minorities and was claimed by an ISIS affiliate.
item.dc:creator: Yaqoob Akbary and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A blast at the Seh Dokan mosque in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan, killed at least 10 people on Thursday.

item.title: This Spanish Village Has More Booksellers Than School Pupils
item.description: Urueña, in northwestern Spain, has fought depopulation by reinventing itself as a literary hub. The full-time population is still just 100, but there are 11 shops selling books.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Páramo bookstore in Urueña, Spain, sells an array of secondhand books. The owner, Víctor López-Bachiller, says the low rent helps him to stay afloat.

item.title: France’s Presidential Election 2022: Your Runoff Questions, Answered
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron will face Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader, in the runoff on Sunday. The outcome will be crucial for France and reverberate globally.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters at a polling station in Versailles, during the first round of the French presidential election earlier this month.

item.title: Ukraine’s Forces, Dug In on Front Line, Fight to Repel Russia
item.description: After near-annihilation, and a marriage proposal, a Ukrainian unit has become a group of hardened veterans, dug in and determined.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: First Lt. Olena Petyak, with the 128th Separate Mountain Assault Brigade, talks with other troops on Friday near the frontlines in the Zaporizka region.

item.title: Hackers Claim to Target Russian Institutions in Barrage of Cyberattacks and Leaks
item.description: While the authenticity of leaked data could not be verified, the effort appears to be part of a campaign by hackers opposed to the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Red Square outside the Kremlin in Moscow. The Ukrainian government appears to have begun a parallel effort to punish Russia by publishing the names of Russian soldiers and agents of the F.S.B., a major Russian intelligence agency.

item.title: Maskless Flying
item.description: What might a more effective mask mandate look like?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting to board a plane in Atlanta.

item.title: Climate Rallies Planned for White House and Across U.S.
item.description: ‘Fight for Our Future’ rallies are planned Saturday for Washington, Atlanta, Phoenix and elsewhere as supporters say time is running out for ambitious climate action.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: As Europe Approves New Tech Laws, the U.S. Falls Further Behind
item.description: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang

item.title: 1922: Sight of Women Smoking A Cigar Shocks Paris
item.description: Two women who shared a Havana cigar in a Parisian restaurant reportedly caused a stir.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Putin prematurely claims victory in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Russian-backed fighter in front of the destroyed administration building at the Azovstal steel factory in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: When Will the Tourists Be Back?
item.description: An industry weathering a long winter looks warily ahead.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Pacific Explorer cruise ship docking at Sydney Harbour on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Says Ukraine Needs $7 Billion in Support per Month
item.description: Ukraine has suffered $550 billion in losses from the war, President Volodymyr Zelensky told the World Bank on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: The aftermath of a Russian rocket strike in a residential neighborhood in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: L.A. County Says Masks Are Still Required on Public Transportation
item.description: The move is a departure from California’s mask rules, which were relaxed this week after a federal judge struck down a nationwide mask mandate on public transit.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new Los Angeles County health order clarifies that people still have to wear masks on public transit, including on buses and in ride-share vehicles and airports.

item.title: Putin Claims Victory in Mariupol, Calling Off Steel Plant Assault
item.description: With casualties mounting and progress slow in his war on Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is eager to present it to the Russian people as a success.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian family arriving in Zaporizhzhia on Thursday after fleeing the Russian-occupied village of Tokmak, near Mariupol.

item.title: Next Phase of War Will Be Pivotal for Russia and Ukraine, U.S. Says
item.description: Reflecting a renewed sense of urgency, President Biden announced that the United States would send the Ukrainians $800 million more in military aid.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Russian rocket struck a residential neighborhood in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday. U.S. officials still expect the war to be long and grinding.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Putin’s Defensive Speech
item.description: The Russian leader claimed victory in Mariupol, despite Ukrainian resistance.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian family who fled Mariupol arrives in Zaporizhzhia.

item.title: US Braces for Potential French Election Shockwave
item.description: An upset victory by the right-wing nationalist Marine Le Pen in the presidential election on Sunday could scramble President Biden’s foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watching at a Paris bar as Marine Le Pen debated President Emmanuel Macron of France on Wednesday.

item.title: What to Know About the Weapons Being Sent to Ukraine
item.description: The Biden administration is sending dozens of howitzers and 120 drones in the latest $800 million package of military aid.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian Volunteer Corps operated a howitzer in the Zaporizhzhia region last month. The United States plans to send additional artillery systems as part of a new $800 million military aid package.

item.title: Mikhail Vasenkov Dies at 79; His Spy Ring Inspired ‘The Americans’
item.description: He and his wife were among 10 Soviet sleeper agents who blended into American society before being exposed and deported in 2010. The TV series sprung from the episode.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Mikhail Vasenkov in 2010, the year he and nine others were arrested by the F.B.I. in a multiyear investigation called Operation Ghost Stories. Accused of being Soviet agents, they were deported in a swap of prisoners with Moscow.

item.title: Biden Announces $800 Million in Military Aid and Questions Russia’s Hold of Mariupol
item.description: President Biden said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would “never succeed in dominating” Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden spoke about new aid packages for Ukraine at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Is Extending a Vaccine Rule for International Travelers at Land Borders
item.description: Unlike air travelers entering the United States, land and ferry travelers will still not have to show a recent negative coronavirus test to cross the border.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Canadian travelers cross into the United States at the Peace Arch border crossing in Blaine, Wash. in November.

item.title: S​outh Korea’s Supreme Court ​Issues Landmark Ruling on Gay Sex
item.description: ​The court said that the military should not punish consensual sex acts that had taken place in a nonmilitary setting.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korean Marines patrolling on Yeonpyeong Island, South Korea, in 2020.

item.title: Perils of Invisible Government
item.description: The American Rescue Plan is huge and yet little noticed.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Parker Michels-Boyce for The New York Times
item.media:description: A home that will be offered for sale at reduced cost with ARP funding in Richmond, Va.

item.title: With Moskva Warship Sunken, Russia Disinformation Faces a Test
item.description: Families of missing crew members say the Russian authorities are giving them the runaround after a flagship sank last week in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: Days after the Russian missile cruiser Moskva was confirmed to have sunk, some relatives of its crew members have not been given information on their relatives’ whereabouts.

item.title: Gazan Militants and Israeli Air Force Exchange Fire
item.description: The flare-up followed a rise in tensions over holy places in Jerusalem and a deadly wave of Arab attacks in Israel, answered by a lethal Israeli crackdown in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Streaks of light illuminated the skies as Israel’s Iron Dome anti-missile system intercepted rockets launched from the Gaza Strip toward Israel on Thursday.

item.title: Kangaroos in India? Experts See Evidence of a Smuggling Trade
item.description: The animals are the latest exotic fauna to be smuggled into the country, possibly to be used as pets. Draft legislation would close loopholes in the roaring wildlife trade.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Sameer Yasir

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A Russian missile test with a message.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Macron and Le Pen Trade Punches in Pivotal French Election Debate
item.description: He attacked the far-right leader as a Putin stooge. She hit back at him as the president of division and contempt.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People at a Paris bar watching the live televised presidential debate between Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen on Wednesday.

item.title: See Mariupol’s Azovstal Steel-Mill Fortress Before the War, and Now
item.description: Before-and-after images show the scale of destruction that the Ukrainian port city has suffered after nearly two months of near constant bombardment by Russian artillery, mortars and airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald

item.title: Russia Tests ICBM and Pounds Ukraine’s Defenses Ahead of Major Assault
item.description: Vladimir Putin said Russia’s test-firing of its new I.C.B.M. sends a message, as his forces prepare for a broad offensive in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Richard Pérez-Peña

item.title: Russia’s Missile Test Fuels U.S. Fears of an Isolated Putin
item.description: American and foreign leaders have been weighing whether their success in making Russia a diplomatic pariah could push President Vladimir V. Putin to strike in new ways.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: American officials have encountered repeated reminders by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that the world is messing with a nuclear weapons power and should tread carefully.

item.title: What Mariupol’s Steel Fortress Looked Like 3 Months Ago
item.description: On Jan. 20, The New York Times captured drone video over the sprawling Azovstal Steel and Iron works complex in Mariupol, Ukraine. Now, it is a battered fortress for the last Ukrainian defenders.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald

item.title: People Should Keep Wearing Masks in Public, W.H.O. Officials Say
item.description: Masks have been proven to be highly effective at reducing coronavirus transmission when used properly, according to the W.H.O.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grand Central Station in Manhattan. World Health Organization officials encouraged people to wear masks in indoor public places and outdoors where social distancing is not possible.

item.title: Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, 95, Dies; Fought for Mexico’s ‘Disappeared’
item.description: When her son vanished in 1975, she began a crusade on behalf of him and hundreds of others and became a voice of moral authority on the left.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Threatens Escalation
item.description: Plus the emergence of armed militias in Colombia and questions over China’s Covid death toll.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maxim and Tanya Khomenko, with the help of their relatives, moved their belongings from their destroyed apartment building in Horenka, northwest of Kyiv, Ukraine.Credit...

item.title: He Was a Penniless Donor to the Far Right. He Was Also a Russian Spy.
item.description: An investigation in Slovakia has exposed how Russian clandestine operations are trying to sow discord in Europe and create sympathy for Moscow over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center in Kosice, Slovakia. The Kremlin has sought to win influence and sow discord on Europe’s formerly communist eastern fringe.

item.title: Residents in Avdiivka, Ukraine Go Underground as Russia’s Assault on East Ramps Up
item.description: As Ukrainian forces dig into trenches and residents flee into basements, Russia’s artillery attacks have intensified. “They can’t get through the front lines and so they’re starting simply to destroy the city,” a Ukrainian official said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Like many other residents of Avdiivka, Ukraine, Matviy, 12, has sought shelter from Russian bombardment in a basement. The village has come under increasing artillery fire as Russia shifts its offensive to Ukraine’s east.

item.title: Barack Obama Takes On a New Role: Fighting Disinformation
item.description: The former president has embarked on a campaign to warn that the scourge of online falsehoods has eroded the foundations of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Cecilia Kang
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama has waded deeply into the public fray over misinformation and disinformation.

item.title: Calls to Give Heavy Weapons to Ukraine Divide Germany’s Government
item.description: Weeks after Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a paradigm shift in military strategy, his government is struggling to balance domestic politics, how to help Ukraine and anxiety over provoking Russia.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Under Chancellor Olaf Scholz and prompted by the war in Ukraine, Germany has turned away from its decades of pacifist policy and toward rearming itself and supplying arms for Ukrainian soldiers.

item.title: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen walked out of a G20 meeting as Russia’s finance minister spoke.
item.description: Several central bank governors and finance ministers protested Russia’s participation at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Prince Harry Said He Wants to Make Sure Queen Is ‘Protected’
item.description: The prince, in Europe for the Invictus Games, visited his grandmother then told the “Today” show that he wanted to make sure “she’s protected.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Housing Crisis Propels High Death Toll in South Africa Floods
item.description: The catastrophe underscored an overlooked reality in the fight against extreme weather: Protecting people is as much about tackling social issues as environmental ones.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Zanele Mji and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The edge of a destroyed bridge in Inanda, north of Durban, on Monday, after weeks of flooding in Kwazulu-Natal Province, South Africa.

item.title: Russia Said It Has Successfully Tested a New ICBM That Can Evade Defenses
item.description: Though officials said the missile is not yet ready to deploy, President Vladimir V. Putin said the launch of the Sarmat missile “will force all who are trying to threaten our country in the heat of frenzied, aggressive rhetoric to think twice.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Russian Defence Ministry
item.media:description: A Sarmat intercontinental ballistic missile was launched by Russia on Wednesday, as seen on this screengrab from video footage released by the Russian Defense Ministry.

item.title: Why ‘Border Control’ Politics Is More About Control Than Borders
item.description: A quirk of political psychology helps explain the British government’s plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrating outside Britain’s Parliament in January against a previously proposed immigration bill.

item.title: U.K. Court Order Moves Assange Closer to Extradition
item.description: The court formally ordered the extradition of the WikiLeaks founder to the United States, but it still needs approval from a British cabinet minister and his defense can appeal to her directly.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange on the balcony of the Embassy of Ecuador in London, in 2017. He sought refuge there for seven years.
